Once, the Buddha was staying at the Kalandaka Bamboo Grove in RÄjagá¹›ha.

At that time, there was a skilled general who was the head of a village. He went to where the Buddha was, bowed his head at the Buddha's feet, and after inquiring about the Buddha's well-being, sat to one side.
He said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
I have heard from the elders of old:

'When going into battle, one must adorn one's weapons, protect oneself well, be brave and go straight forward without fear, able to break through the enemy, injure and kill living beings, causing the remaining troops to all retreat and scatter.
Having done this, one will be reborn in the Heaven Adorned with Arrows after death.'
At that time, the general asked this, and the Buddha told him:
Stop!
Do not speak.
What you are asking about now is very unwholesome.
The second and third times he asked in the same way.
The Buddha again told him:
You have earnestly asked me three times. If you can accept it, I will tell you.
Those who fight must protect themselves well, be skilled in battle tactics, be at the forefront of the formation, and advance bravely.
Such a warrior, would he not intentionally and skillfully wish to harm those enemy troops, thinking like this:
'How can I bind them, harm them, and destroy them completely?
' Would he not give rise to such thoughts?
Warrior!
You have given rise to the three kinds of evil karma towards sentient beings.
What are called the three kinds of evil karma?
Namely, they are the body, speech, and mind.
If one, by means of such three unwholesome karmas, upon the dissolution of the body and the end of life, were to be reborn in the heavens, there is no such possibility.
Warrior!
If you now see in this way, this is wrong view.
The karma of wrong view will definitely give rise to two places, either in hell or falling into the animal realm.
At that time, the fighting general, having heard the Buddha's words, wept with tears streaming down.
The Buddha again said:
For this reason, I have requested three times not to speak.
I will now tell you, why are you weeping?
Then the general said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
I am not grieving because of hearing this teaching;

I feel pity for those who engage in battle, who are foolish and ignorant for a long time, who are childish and lack wisdom, who always do unwholesome deeds, and who will receive great suffering in the future.
Such evil karma will truly not lead to rebirth in the heavens.
If one were to be reborn in the Arrow-Adorned Heaven due to this karma, it would truly be impossible.
World-Honored One!
From now on, I will never again give rise to such wrong views.

Excellent!

Once, the Buddha was staying at the Kalandaka Bamboo Grove in RÄjagá¹›ha.
At that time, there was a village head named Evil Nature who went to where the Buddha was, bowed his head at the Buddha's feet, and sat to one side.
He then said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
There are people in the world who do not cultivate anything, who trouble and touch others, and speak words that trouble and touch others.
Therefore, all people call such a person extremely evil.
The Buddha told the village headman:
Suppose there is a person who offends and harms others, speaks offensive words, and because of speaking offensive words, causes others to become angry. For this reason, he is called ill-tempered.

He does not cultivate right view, right action, right speech, right livelihood, right mindfulness, right effort, right intention, or right concentration. Because he does not cultivate right concentration, he offends and harms others.
Because he offends and harms, he becomes extremely angry.ğŸ”½Because he is angry, he speaks angry words.
Because he speaks angry words, he is called ill-tempered.
Then the village headman said:
It is rare, Gautama!
It is truly as you say. Because of being offended, he is indeed called ill-tempered.
Because I do not cultivate right view, I am offended by him.
Because I am offended, he calls me ill-tempered.
All the people in the world call me ill-tempered. From then on, I am called ill-tempered.
The village chief said again:
Gautama!
How can one avoid being irritated?
Because of being free from irritation, one can speak without irritation.
Even if one is irritated by others, one does not irritate others.
Even if one is spoken to irritably by others, one does not speak irritably to them in return.
Even if one is irritated by others, one does not give rise to mental irritation.
Because of being free from irritation, people all praise one as a patient and good person, and they also give rise to the thought of patience and goodness towards them.
If it is like this, one can cultivate right view.
Because of cultivating right view, one has right action, right speech, right livelihood, right intention, right effort, right concentration, and right mindfulness.
Because of cultivating right concentration, one is touched by others but does not give rise to irritation.
Because of not giving rise to irritation, it is called patience and goodness.
The village chief said:
It is rare, Gautama!
What you have said is excellent.
It is just as you say. Because I did not cultivate right views, I was troubled by others.
Because I was troubled by others, I spoke words of irritation. Therefore, worldly people call me ill-tempered, and all give rise to evil thoughts, so I am called ill-tempered.
Because I did not cultivate the eightfold right path, I was touched by others and spoke words of irritation, and thus ended up with anger and resentment.
Because of these thoughts, worldly people call me ill-tempered.
The village headman said:
Gautama!
From now on, I will abandon this ill-temper, sudden violence, arrogance, and ferocity.
The Buddha praised him, saying:
If you can do this, it is truly excellent.
Then, the village headman, having heard the Buddha's teachings, joyfully bowed in reverence and left.
126. At that time, there was a village head named Wish-Fulfilling Pearl Topknot, who went to where the Buddha was, bowed at the Buddha's feet, sat to one side, and said to the Buddha:

Once, the Buddha was staying at the bank of the Ghoá¹£irÄ River in CampÄ.
At that time, the village headman named King Topknot came to where the Buddha was, bowed his head at the Buddha's feet, and sat to one side.
The Buddha told him:
In this world, there are many beings who rely on two kinds of dharmas:
First, the pleasure of desire, second, the practice of what is useless.
Bodily acts are not the Dharma of the sages, in vain one experiences what is useless and harmful.
Practicing the pleasure of desire is called the Dharma of the lowly and the bound.
There are three kinds of people who experience the pleasure of desire.
What are the three?

First, accumulating unlawful wealth, harming the lives of beings, enjoying one's own body, and creating the causes for one's own true pleasure, this is also not called making offerings to one's parents, nor is it called giving to one's wife, children, and servants, nor is it called for one's relatives, friends, and associates, nor is it called making offerings to and supporting Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and the fields of merit.
If it is like this, one does not cultivate the supreme path, does not create the causes for pleasure, and does not obtain the reward of pleasure. This is called the first kind of pleasure of desire.

Even if they enjoy sensual pleasures, sometimes in accordance with the Dharma, sometimes not, sometimes harming others, sometimes not, they bring happiness to themselves, and bring happiness to their parents, wives, children, servants, friends, relatives, and supporters, all of whom they provide for and serve, giving them true happiness. However, they do not give to Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmans, or fields of merit, nor do they cultivate the right path, create causes for happiness, seek happy rewards, or create causes for rebirth in the heavens. This is called the second kind of sensual pleasure.
The Buddha further told the village headman:

If one accumulates wealth and treasures in accordance with the Dharma, and uses them to harm others, because of acting in accordance with the Dharma, not creating evil through harming others, cultivating one's own body, and rightly enjoying pleasures, this is also called rightly making offerings to one's parents, and providing with peace and happiness one's wife, children, servants, friends, relatives, and those who assist one, and rightly providing for them.

From time to time making offerings to Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as, establishing fields of merit, cultivating the supreme path, planting the causes of happiness, seeking the rewards of happiness, and creating the causes for rebirth in the heavens, this is called the third kind of enjoying sensual pleasures.
I now explain for all those who enjoy sensual pleasures.ğŸ”½If one enjoys sensual pleasures, I say it is inferior.
If one enjoys sensual pleasures, I say it is middling.
If one enjoys sensual pleasures, I say it is superior.
What is inferior?

If one accumulates wealth through improper means or even through proper means, but does not enjoy it oneself or create the causes for one's own happiness, and also does not make offerings to one's wife, children, servants, friends, and relatives, nor make timely offerings to Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and various fields of merit, does not cultivate the supreme path, does not create the causes for happiness, does not obtain the rewards of happiness, and does not create the causes for rebirth in the heavens, this is called inferior.
What is called middling?

If one enjoys sensual pleasures, sometimes through proper means, sometimes through improper means, sometimes causing harm to oneself, but still brings happiness to one's parents, wife, children, servants, relatives, and so forth, up to not creating the causes for rebirth in the heavens, this is called middling.
What is called superior?

Namely, accumulating wealth in accordance with the Dharma, not engaging in harm, experiencing bodily pleasure, properly making offerings to parents, spouse, children, servants, and friends, and even being able to create causes for rebirth in the heavens. This is called the superior.
What are the three kinds of harmful practices that bring suffering to the body?
Namely, suffering that is not the noble Dharma, which lacks meaning and benefit. If one brings suffering to the body, the mind will be corrupted.
First, violating precepts causes the body and mind, inside and outside, to become hot all at once. Reflecting on this matter, one is never free from it for a moment.

In the present world, one is not free from vexation and heat, and one will never be able to attain the Dharma that surpasses the human realm. This is called the first harmful practice that brings suffering to the body.

If there are people who, although not violating precepts, still do not change their minds, but rather praise the two karmas of body and mind, and practice this while being comfortable inside and outside, in the present world they are not free from afflictions and will never be able to attain the Dharma that surpasses the human realm. This is called the second harmful practice that brings suffering to the body.

Furthermore, if there are people who, although not breaking the precepts, still do not change their minds, but rather praise the two karmas of body and mind, internally and externally both being suitable, cultivating mindfulness of this matter, in the present world not being free from afflictions, having a little progress beyond human dharmas, or attaining a little wisdom, or attaining the view of dharmas, or a little meditation and concentration, this is called the third useless suffering of the body.
Head of a village!

I also do not say that useless ascetic practices are all of one kind. There are ascetic practices called inferior, there are ascetic practices called middling, and there are ascetic practices called superior.
What is called inferior?

When first breaking the precepts, the mind has already degenerated, and body and mind internally and externally are all heated, recollecting this matter without a moment's respite, in the present world not being free from afflictions, ultimately unable to attain dharmas beyond human dharmas, this is called inferior.
What is called middling?

If there are people who, although not violating precepts, their minds also do not change, and yet they accord with the two karmas of body and mind, both internally and externally, and cultivate this matter, in the present life they are not free from afflictions, and also cannot attain the Dharma beyond the human realm, this is called middling.
What is called superior?

If there are people who, although not violating precepts, their minds do not change, and yet they accord with the two karmas of body and mind, both internally and externally, and cultivate this matter, in the present they cannot permanently sever all afflictions, but have some progress beyond the human Dharma, either attaining little wisdom, or attaining the Dharma of seeing, or touching the bliss of meditation, this is called superior.
For, village chief!

Excluding these two extremes, one should head towards the middle way, namely the three kinds of sensual pleasures and the three kinds of self-mortification that are harmful to the body, one should head towards the middle way.
What is meant by abandoning the three kinds of desires and pleasures, as well as the three kinds of harmful suffering, and heading towards the middle way?
Head of the village!

Being tainted by desires and pleasures, one harms oneself, also harms others, and harms both oneself and others. In the present, one accumulates all kinds of evil, and in the future, one also accumulates all kinds of evil.
For this reason, one's mind is troubled and sorrowful, and one experiences all kinds of suffering and distress.

Even if one exhausts the bonds of desire, one does not harm oneself, nor does one harm others, nor does one have suffering for oneself or others. In the present world, one does not accumulate suffering, and in the future world, one also does not accumulate all kinds of suffering. For this reason, one attains happiness in the present life, is free from various afflictions and distress, does not choose the time and season, and attains closeness to nirvana.

In the present world, one is able to attain the fruit of the path. The wise one knows for oneself, clearly and without obstruction, and does not follow the teachings of others. This is called the middle way from the beginning.
Head of the village!

There is also a middle way that is free from vexation and heat, not choosing time or season, that can approach nirvana. The wise know for themselves and do not follow the teachings of others. It refers to right view, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right concentration, right effort, right intention, and right mindfulness. This is called the second middle way.
When this Dharma was being spoken, the village headman with hair in a topknot far from dust and free from defilements, attained the purity of the Dharma eye.

At that time, the village headman with hair in a topknot knew the Dharma, saw the Dharma, attained the Dharma, crossed over doubt and reached the other shore, was free from doubt and uncertainty, did not follow the teachings of others, did not accept different views, and attained unobstructed eloquence in the Buddha's teachings.
He immediately rose from his seat, adjusted his robes, joined his palms towards the Buddha, and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!

Today, I have already escaped and taken refuge in the Buddha, and I also take refuge in the Dharma and the Sangha, the Two Treasures. I uphold the precepts of an upÄsaka. From now until the end of my life, I take refuge in the Three Treasures.
At that time, the village headman Wang Dingfa heard what the Buddha said, rejoiced and leaped with joy, bowed his head and left.

At that time, the village headman Donkey-surname heard from afar that the World-Honored One was traveling through the villages of Mala and had arrived at the village of UrubilvÄ, in the forest of myrobalan trees in the parrot grove. He thought like this:

At that time, the donkey-surname brahmin, having contemplated this, left the village and went to where the World-Honored One was. He bowed at the Buddha's feet and sat to one side.

If I were to tell you about the Dharma of eliminating immeasurable past sufferings and afflictions, you might believe it or not, or like it or not.
I now also wish to tell you about the Dharma of eliminating immeasurable future sufferings and afflictions, but you might believe it or not, or like it or not.
The Buddha further said:
I will now explain to you right here the Dharma for extinguishing suffering and its causes. You should listen carefully and keep it in mind.

All sentient beings give rise to small sufferings, and within these sufferings there are various distinctions. These various sufferings arise from desire, and they are all due to desire. Desire is the root and the cause and condition.
Then the village headman again said to the Buddha:

World-Honored One!
Now my faculties are dull and I do not understand the brief explanation. I only pray that out of compassion you will extensively expound this meaning and enable me to awaken.

Now I will ask you, and you may answer as you wish.

In this UrubilvÄ village, those whom I love can give rise to my sorrow, grief, and distress, and my mind will not be at ease;
Those whom I do not love, whom I do not desire, and whom I do not think of, I will have no sorrow, grief, or distress towards them.

. He further said to the Buddha:

If my son were far away, I would send a messenger to check on him. If the messenger returned slowly, my mind and that of his mother would be uneasy. We would wonder why the messenger was slow, and whether our son was not safe.
